data.text: Are WTB Exposure Tires Any Good?

These WTB Exposure tires (photos and link here) came with the gravel bike I just bought. How do people think the tires will perform on somewhat loose dirt/somewhat rocky trail (Marin Headlands)? Should I get something with more tread? https://www.wtb.com/products/exposure

I love wide "slicks" on gravel, but they aren't excellent in loose or rocks... they fly on 'groomed' and well packed/hardpack gravel but thats what I try to stick to when on one of my gravel bikes with 38 slicks...
data.author: Steve Heintzelman

data.text: I have these same tires 700x36 and they are great on road and a packed surface. I like a little big or knobs if I am going to do any type of gravel.
data.author: Keith Rice

data.text: I find riding off-road with with wide slicks to be ultra educational to how you should handle a bike. Once you wear through those, anything with bite will feel like a treat üëç

data.text: I've ridden quite a bit in the Marin Headlands. I've used a number of different tires and like any ride really, it's all about how fast you plan to ride, the tires your riding mates are using and the weather. In the wet, these get scary and trying to keep up with a rowdy group on a descent gets really scary in the corners. In short, you can get away with these but be prepared to go slowly. I prefer the Maxxis Ramblers or the WTB Resolutes in that area for what it's worth.
data.author: Jerome Guerard

data.text: Just learn how to do a controlled slide when bombing down repack. üôÇ I use to ride slicks on my 26" MT bike from Novato through Lucas valley road cutting through the hills to Fairfax. Side treads would help.
data.author: Edc Olin

data.text: I've got a lot of experience on these same tires, 650x47. Zero sidewall traction makes cornering interesting and be careful going up steeps as it's easy to loose traction. You can ride anything on them but there are better options. Gravel King SK's tubeless and pretty good for me. Enough traction and still fast enough on pavement.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: Look great on pavement or even chipseal. Otherwise, nope.
data.author: Benjamin Arians

data.text: Getchu a pair of Rene Herse knobbies or Gravelking SK's
data.author: Luis A Vega

data.text: I had these on my Lekker commuter bike. They were great on road but didn't handle quartz gravel at all. They were sliced up pretty badly by sharp stones. Have tried other WTB tyres with similar results... they seem quite soft. I've now changed to American Classic tyres... excellent puncture protection.
data.author: John Holton

data.text: On loose gravel you are sliding rocks over rocks, slicks work as good as anything. Only in mud or on wet grass are they not good.

data.text: schwalbe smart sam is easily overlooked, but makes more sense on mixed terrain than any other tyre I rode (gravelking sk, wtb raddler, continental doublefighter, schwalbe cx, vittoria terreno...) the downside is they are not expensive enough to show off...

data.text: Knobbies don't provide any additional traction over slicks on loose gravel. Knobbies only provide additional traction in loose (or damp/wet) dirt, and only when cornering or under heavy acceleration or braking. Even slicks will float sand surprisingly well. Also, similar tires with a "file" type tread will perform noticeably better than a full slick, and are usually less weight than similar knobbies. Ride these tires, try them on every surface.
data.author: Chris Hereford

data.text: Definitely swap them if your riding gravel or loose dirt etc
